<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 722, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|> 9702/33 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 359, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|> May/June 2022 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 285, 450]]<|/det|> Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 808, 467]]<|/det|> Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|> Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|> Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 480, 512]]<|/det|> Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 358, 527]]<|/det|> Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 798, 544]]<|/det|> You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 544, 892, 575]]<|/det|> You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 320, 590]]<|/det|> You may use a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 590, 578, 606]]<|/det|> You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 635, 220, 650]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 651, 384, 666]]<|/det|> The total mark for this paper is 40. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 667, 729, 683]]<|/det|> The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[680, 732, 905, 860]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 868, 611, 884]]<|/det|> This document has 12 pages.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 740, 90]]<|/det|>
**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 96, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 594, 121]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate an electrical circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 658, 151]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with a wooden strip with a wire attached.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 164, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the length \(L\) of the wire between the nails on the wooden strip, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 203, 787, 300]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 317, 533, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 378, 920, 397]]<|/det|>
<form>L = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 828, 90]]<|/det|>
You have also been provided with a wire labelled A with crocodile clips at its ends.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 103, 180, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 102, 487, 121]]<|/det|>
Set up the circuit shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 129, 809, 395]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 413, 534, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 445, 175, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 444, 463, 463]]<|/det|>
F, G, H and J are crocodile clips.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 475, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
The distance between one of the nails and H is \(d\), as shown in Fig. 1.2. Attach H to the wire on the wooden strip so that \(d\) is approximately \(20 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 522, 175, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 522, 339, 541]]<|/det|>
Close the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 553, 175, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 552, 690, 571]]<|/det|>
Record the value of \(d\) and the voltmeter readings \(V_{1}\) and \(V_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 597, 917, 616]]<|/det|>
<form>d = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 630, 917, 649]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{1} = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 662, 917, 681]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{2} = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 692, 178, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 692, 336, 710]]<|/det|>
Open the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 706, 920, 725]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 806, 91]]<|/det|>
Increase \(d\) by placing H at different positions on the wire and record \(V_{1}\) and \(V_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 84, 875, 106]]<|/det|>
Repeat until you have six sets of readings of \(d\), \(V_{1}\) and \(V_{2}\). Include your values from **(b)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 774, 144]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\left(\frac{V_2}{V_1}\right)d\) and \(d^2\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 528, 920, 546]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 560, 144, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 555, 176, 576]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 549, 685, 585]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\left(\frac{V_2}{V_1}\right)d\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(d^2\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 559, 920, 578]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 591, 180, 610]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 588, 457, 609]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 590, 920, 609]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 621, 181, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 621, 608, 640]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 821, 917, 841]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 853, 917, 873]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 870, 920, 889]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 764, 92]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the quantities \(V_{1}, V_{2}\) and \(d\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 98, 569, 135]]<|/det|>
\[\left(\frac{V_2}{V_1}\right)d = Pd^2 + Q\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 140, 405, 159]]<|/det|>
where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 171, 655, 191]]<|/det|>
Using your answers in **(d)(iii)**, determine values for \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 187, 346, 205]]<|/det|>
Give appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 282, 917, 301]]<|/det|>
<form>P = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 313, 917, 331]]<|/det|>
<form>Q = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 330, 920, 349]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 361, 143, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 361, 650, 380]]<|/det|>
Wire A has the same length \(L\) as the wire between the nails.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 392, 334, 410]]<|/det|>
Theory suggests that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 415, 591, 445]]<|/det|>
\[P = -\frac{1}{L}\quad \mathrm{and}\quad Q = L.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 452, 757, 472]]<|/det|>
A student repeats the experiment using two shorter wires of equal length.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 484, 685, 503]]<|/det|>
Sketch a second line on the graph to show the expected results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 500, 299, 518]]<|/det|>
Label this line W.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 500, 920, 518]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 530, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 20]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 740, 89]]<|/det|>
**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 103, 97, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 744, 120]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the motion of two connected masses.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 648, 151]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with two masses connected by a string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 567, 166]]<|/det|>
The larger mass is \(100\mathrm{g}\) and the smaller mass is \(10\mathrm{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 144, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 180, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 180, 584, 198]]<|/det|>
● Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 205, 769, 484]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 497, 532, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 529, 210, 546]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 528, 920, 577]]<|/det|>
Hold the \(10\mathrm{g}\) mass so that the string is horizontal and as straight as possible and the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass is as close to the rod of the clamp as possible. The string should be resting on the rod of the clamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 591, 794, 607]]<|/det|>
When the \(10\mathrm{g}\) mass is released, the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass will fall downwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 606, 658, 622]]<|/det|>
The \(10\mathrm{g}\) mass will fall and move towards the stand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 622, 789, 638]]<|/det|>
The string will wrap itself several times around the rod of the clamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 652, 883, 669]]<|/det|>
You may need to repeat the procedure several times before you see this result.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 222, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 428, 88]]<|/det|>
Release the \(10\mathrm{g}\) mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 102, 220, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 102, 761, 121]]<|/det|>
The distance fallen by the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass is \(A\), as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 128, 621, 390]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 403, 534, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 435, 425, 453]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 559, 922, 577]]<|/det|>
<form>\(A =\) .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 590, 181, 608]]<|/det|>
